section.title: Structured Data Enables Enhanced AI Output
section.para: By collaboratively enhancing and integrating existing laboratory standards, clinical care organizations can reduce maintenance burdens and move towards achieving data interoperability, enabling scalable solutions as the healthcare ecosystem evolves. Healthcare must move beyond siloed, fragmented data toward integrated, curated information that powers intelligent systems. Our logical model, backed by the HL7 Tinkar ballot, helps enable this approach by enhancing the quality of healthcare data, unlocking reliable innovation, faster decision-making, and improved interoperability. Flexible data structures that can adapt to changes in regulatory and clinical requirements are needed so that both human and Artificial Intelligence systems can continue to use and benefit from the data as the healthcare landscape evolves. The structured data can then serve as the backbone for advancing AI capabilities in healthcare.

Currently, AI systems often struggle with gaps and inconsistencies due to unstructured data, such as free text, resulting in variable answers and hallucinated responses. A recent study published in the Journal of the American Medical Association demonstrates that AI models perform dramatically better when enriched with linked, structured information, improving accuracy and reliability in complex tasks such as the US Medical Licensing Examinations [6].

As public health agencies explore AI implementations, the data model provides various capabilities that offer a robust data foundation to support reliable large language models and regulatory automation. Device Extension (DeX) is one of the many use cases enabled by the model. DeX creates a machine-readable network of relationships across identifiers and attributes, providing an extendable pathway for AI tools to consistently reason across datasets and deliver more accurate answers. It helps to organize and connect critical device data, (such as product codes, manufacture data, naming conventions, detection limits, reference ranges, etc.) by capturing essential information from sources such as SNOMED, LOINC, and GUDID databases and define relationships between devices, attributes, and regulatory metadata. Komet plays a key role in structuring the information, as it works to create and store DeX content. The interface also helps edit and reliably manage existing relationships as device data evolves over time and export these relationships in standard, computable formats that AI systems can easily ingest.

To take advantage of these functionalities, a robust data pipeline is essential to help transform raw, fragmented healthcare information into structured, high-quality datasets that fuel advanced AI systems. Industry leading tools such as GitHub, Maven, SonarCloud, and more are used to help strengthen the data pipeline, which can then systematically ingest, validate, and link data from diverse sources, including laboratory standards, device registries, and regulatory databases, to ensure consistency, completeness, and interoperability. This process not only eliminates inaccuracies but also enriches the data with meaningful relationships and metadata, making it readily accessible for AI models. Supported by this strengthened data pipeline, AI systems can deliver more accurate, reliable, and context-aware insights, enabling complex decision-making and driving innovation across clinical, regulatory, and public health domains.

Looking forward, our flexible, interoperable data model supports a diverse array of use cases across the healthcare ecosystem. For example, it can support population health analytics by aggregating and harmonizing data from multiple sources, enhance clinical decision support tools that require real-time access to accurate information, and facilitate regulatory reporting by automating the extraction and submission of required data. Researchers can leverage higher quality data to accelerate healthcare advancements, while public health agencies can more confidently rely on data to help respond to emerging health threats. By providing a reliable foundation for these and many other applications, the logical model provides a reliable foundation to enhance the output of evolving technological capabilities in the healthcare ecosystem.
